questions.text: Where would the eggs/ova of helminths be concentrated by the formol-ether technique shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Formal ether technique is a widely used technique for stool examination. Concentration procedure separate parasite from fecal debris and increase the chances of detecting parasitic organisms when these are in small numbers.

They are divided into flotation technique and sedimentation technique.

Procedure mix small portion of stool about the size of marble, in 10 ml 5 -10 % formalin in a test tube. Allow to stand 30 min for fixation. Strain about 10 ml of this suspension through a small funnel containing wet gauze into a 15 ml centrifuge tube. Use two layers of gauze.

The suspension should yield about 0.75 ml of sediment for fresh specimens and 0.5 ml for formalinized feces.

Decant the supernatant and wash the sediment with 10 ml of saline solution. Centrifuge again and repeat washing until supernatant is clear.

After the last wash, decant the supernatant and add 10 ml of 10 % formalin to the sediment. Mix and let stand for 5 min to effect fixation.

Add 1 to 2 ml of ethyl acetate, stopper the tube and shake vigorously,

Centrifuge at 450 g RCF ( about 1500 rpm) for 10 min. Four layers should result as follow

  1. A top layer of ethyl acetate
  2. Plug of debris
  3. Layer of formalin
  4. Sediment
  5. Free the plug of debris from the side of the tube by ringing with an applicator stick. Carefully decan the top three layers

The 4th layer has parasitic eggs.

Key Takeaway:

The Formol-Ether Concentration Technique separates stool components into four layers after centrifugation. Helminth eggs and protozoan cysts concentrate in the sediment layer (Layer 4), making it the correct choice for microscopic examination.

questions.text: The epidemiological cycle of the organism is shown. Which of the following is the vector-
questions.solution:
Mite life cycle is as follow.

Mites develops in four stages. Eg, larva, nymph and adult

However there are typically a single larval stage and two nymphal stages ( The protonymph and deutonymph) in the life cycle.

The number of nymphal generation may be less or more in some species.

Most species of mites are important from standpoint of veterinary science as they cause transmission of several disease to domestic as well as other subhuman vertebrates. Some species also transmit human disease.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:
Choice B: Hard Tick – Hard ticks (Ixodidae) are vectors for several bacterial and viral infections, such as Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi) and Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii), but they are not the vector for mite-associated diseases.

Choice C: Soft Tick – Soft ticks (Argasidae) transmit relapsing fever caused by Borrelia spp. and viral hemorrhagic fevers, but they do not act as the vector in this epidemiological cycle.

Choice D: Louse – Lice are responsible for transmitting epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), trench fever (Bartonella quintana), and louse-borne relapsing fever (Borrelia recurrentis), but not mite-borne diseases.

Key Takeaway:
Mites play a crucial role in transmitting rickettsial diseases such as scrub typhus, while ticks and lice are responsible for other bacterial infections. Understanding the specific vector for each disease is essential for diagnosis and prevention.

choices.text: It is lactose fermenting on MacConkey medium

questions.text: Scrub typhus, all true except-
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is caused by orientia tsutsugamushi ( Formerly known at R tsutsugamushi, R orientalis), It was first observed in japan where it was transmitted by mites.

It occurs where there is a suitable environment, plenty of moisture and scrub vegetation. Mite inhabit sharply demarcated areas in the soil where  the micro ecosystem is favourable ( Mite islands).

Human gets infection when they trespass into these mite island and get bitten by mite larvae ( Chiggers)

Man is accidental host

Clinically the patient develops eschar at the site of bite and lymphadenopathy ..

So Option c is wrong , that it produces lactose fermentation on macconkey agar.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:
Choice A: Transmitted by chiggers – Correct
Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers, the larval stage of Leptotrombidium mites. These mites reside in specific ecological zones known as "mite islands," where they act as vectors for the disease.

Choice B: Lymphadenopathy is a feature – Correct
Scrub typhus commonly presents with fever, eschar formation at the bite site, lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms like headache, myalgia, and rash.

Choice D: Man is an accidental host – Correct
Humans are accidental hosts of Orientia tsutsugamushi. The natural reservoir consists of mites and small mammals. Humans acquire the infection when bitten by infected chiggers in mite-infested areas.

Key Takeaway:
Scrub typhus is an intracellular bacterial infection transmitted by chiggers. It does not grow on MacConkey agar as it is not a lactose-fermenting bacterium. The disease is characterized by eschar formation, fever, and lymphadenopathy, with humans serving as accidental hosts.

questions.text: Type of diphtheria vaccine-
questions.solution:
Vaccines are of many types. Live, live attenuated, killed and toxoid.

Organism which produces toxins, this toxin is treated by many ways ( Heating, treating with formaldehyde etc) to make it non pathogenic and converting it into toxoid.

This toxoid works as a vaccine.

So diphtheria is a toxin vaccine.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:
Choice A: Live attenuated – Incorrect
Live attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of the pathogen that can replicate but do not cause disease. Examples include BCG, MMR, and oral polio vaccine (OPV). Diphtheria does not use a live attenuated vaccine.

Choice B: Killed – Incorrect
Killed (inactivated) vaccines contain pathogens that have been killed by heat, chemicals, or radiation. Examples include inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), rabies vaccine, and hepatitis A vaccine. The diphtheria vaccine does not fall into this category.

Choice D: Polysaccharide – Incorrect
Polysaccharide vaccines use purified capsular polysaccharides to induce immunity, often requiring conjugation to a protein carrier for better immunogenicity (e.g., pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccines). Diphtheria is caused by a toxin, not a capsular polysaccharide, so this category is incorrect.

Key Takeaway:
The diphtheria vaccine is a toxoid vaccine, meaning it contains an inactivated form of the diphtheria toxin that induces an immune response without causing disease.

questions.text: GeneXpert System detects mutation in which gene?
questions.solution:
Gene Xpertsystem detects growth of Mycobacteria in sputum along with its resistance to rifampicin.

It detects mutations in the rpoB gene.

Genexpert instrument is to automate and integrate sample purification, nucleic acid amplification, and detection of the target sequence using real time PCR assays.
It is very fast. It was detected in 2 hrs.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:
Choice A: RD1 – Incorrect
The RD1 (Region of Difference 1) gene is associated with virulence factors in M. tuberculosis and is absent in Mycobacterium bovis BCG strains. It is not involved in rifampicin resistance and is not the target of the GeneXpert system.

Choice B: inhA – Incorrect
The inhA gene is linked to isoniazid resistance, not rifampicin resistance. Mutations in inhA affect the mycolic acid biosynthesis pathway, leading to isoniazid resistance, which is detected by other molecular tests but not GeneXpert.

Choice D: katG – Incorrect
The katG gene encodes catalase-peroxidase, which is required for activation of isoniazid (INH). Mutations in katGlead to isoniazid resistance but have no role in rifampicin resistance, making this answer incorrect.

Key Takeaway:
GeneXpert detects rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene of M. tuberculosis. It is a rapid diagnostic tool that provides results in 2 hours, improving early detection and management of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Isotype switching occurs in which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Isotype switching is when B cell starts produces Ig M first then after some time switch to produce IgG.

This process occurs once infection converts from acute to chronic.

This type of isotype switching does not occur for T cells. It has no role in cell mediated immunity.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:
Choice A: Helper T cells – Incorrect
Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) play an indirect role in isotype switching by releasing cytokines such as IL-4, IL-5, IFN-γ, which guide B cells in selecting the appropriate antibody class. However, they do not undergo isotype switching themselves.

Choice B: Cytotoxic T cells – Incorrect
Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in cell-mediated immunity, directly killing infected or cancerous cells. They do not produce antibodies and do not undergo isotype switching.

Choice C: B cell – Incorrect
Naïve B cells initially produce IgM and IgD but do not undergo class switching until they are activated by an antigen and receive signals from helper T cells. Only activated B cells switch antibody classes.

Key Takeaway:
Isotype switching occurs only in activated B cells, allowing them to switch from IgM to IgG, IgA, or IgE, depending on the immune response needed. This process is crucial for producing more effective antibodies against different pathogens.

choices.text: Globally the most common species among them to cause diarrhea is C. parvum
Oocyst is infective immediately after coming out in stool
They do not have the property of internal autoinfection

questions.text: Immunocompromised patient after renal transplantation c/o chronic diarrhoea. On staining the stool by Kinyoun stain, 4-6 microns. Which is true?
questions.solution:
This is opportunistic organism causing diarrhea in immuno compromised case. And the structure in stool is acid fast.

Cryptospora, cyclospora, isosporas can cause this.
They can be differentiated by size of oocyst. All are equally acid fast, 1 % H2so4 is required for doing modified zn staining .

Globally the most common species among them to cause diarrhea is not C parvum.

They are not obligate intracellular.

They have the property of internal autoinfection.

Oocyst coming out in stool is effective immediately. So option B is correct.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Globally the most common species among them to cause diarrhea is C. parvum – Incorrect
While C. parvum is a well-known cause of diarrhea, the most common species causing cryptosporidiosis globally is actually C. hominis. C. parvum is more commonly associated with zoonotic transmission, while C. hominis is more frequently transmitted human-to-human.

Choice C: Obligate intracellular – Incorrect
Cryptosporidium species are not strictly obligate intracellular parasites. While they attach to and invade intestinal epithelial cells, they remain extracytoplasmic, enclosed within a specialized parasitophorous vacuole that allows them to survive while still interacting with the host cell.

Choice D: They do not have the property of internal autoinfection – Incorrect
Cryptosporidium does exhibit internal autoinfection, which is a key feature allowing persistent infection in immunocompromised patients. This occurs when thin-walled oocysts rupture within the host intestine, leading to reinfection without the need for external transmission.

Key Takeaway:

Cryptosporidium species, particularly C. hominis and C. parvum, cause severe chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The oocysts are immediately infective upon excretion, contributing to rapid transmission. Unlike Cyclospora, they do not require maturation in the environment and can undergo internal autoinfection, making infections difficult to clear in immunosuppressed individuals.

choices.text: Can be cultured on cell free medium
Bilateral infiltrates may be seen on XRC

questions.text: All are features of Mycoplasma pneumonia except-
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma are the smallest free living organism, and are prokaryotes.

They lack cell wall, and are bounded by a triple layered until membrane that contains sterol ( thereformycoplasm require sterol for growth.

Their Lack of cell wall is associated with cellular pleomorphism and resistance to cell wall active antimicrobial agents, such as penicillium and cephalosporins.

Mycoplasma are free living ( not obligate intracellular ) and can be cultivated in cell free media.

They have no cell was thats why amoxyclav has no role in treatment.

When it infects lungs bilateral infiltrates can be seen.

Antibodies are produced against it, which helps in lab diagnosis.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Can be cultured on cell-free medium – Correct
Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a free-living organism and can be cultured on cell-free media. Specialized media such as Eaton's agar (enriched with sterols) are used for its cultivation. Unlike obligate intracellular bacteria, it does not require host cells for survival.

Choice C: Bilateral infiltrates may be seen on XRC – Correct
Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes "atypical pneumonia", which is often associated with bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray (CXR). The radiological findings may appear worse than the clinical presentation, a classic feature of Mycoplasma pneumonia.

Choice D: Antibodies useful in diagnosis – Correct
Serological tests detecting anti-Mycoplasma IgM and IgG antibodies are commonly used in diagnosis. Additionally, cold agglutinins (IgM autoantibodies against RBCs) may be elevated in Mycoplasma infections.

Key Takeaway:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, making it resistant to β-lactam antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin-clavulanate). It causes atypical pneumonia, often with bilateral infiltrates on CXR. Diagnosis can be supported by serology (IgM/IgG antibodies) and cold agglutinins. Macrolides, tetracyclines, or fluoroquinolones are the preferred treatment options.

questions.text: Work of (vaccine for SARS COV-2 is done in-
questions.solution:
In microbiology there are four BSL ( Biosafety levels). BSL1, BSL 2, BSL 3 and BSL 4

Depending on severity of infecting organism, different BSL is used.

COVID was easily transmitted among peoples, and it produced pandemic. So BSL 3 is required for work done related to COVID.

Vaccine production for COVID 19 is to be done in BSL 3.

EBOLA, CCHF requires BSL 4.

E coli causing diarrhea, food poisoning are to be processed in BSL 1
Shigella, salmonella etc to be processed in BSL 2.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: BSL-1 – Incorrect
BSL-1 is used for organisms that are non-pathogenic to humans and pose minimal risk, such as E. coli K-12. It is not sufficient for handling highly infectious viruses like SARS-CoV-2.

Choice B: BSL-2 – Incorrect
BSL-2 is required for handling moderately hazardous organisms, such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Staphylococcus aureus. While some routine diagnostic work on SARS-CoV-2 (e.g., PCR testing of patient samples) may occur at BSL-2 with additional precautions, live virus culture and vaccine research require BSL-3 containment.

Choice D: BSL-4 – Incorrect
BSL-4 is reserved for highly lethal viruses with no available treatment or vaccine, such as Ebola virus and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus. SARS-CoV-2 does not require BSL-4 because effective containment measures exist at BSL-3.

Key Takeaway:

SARS-CoV-2 vaccine research requires BSL-3 containment due to its high transmissibility and potential for severe disease. BSL-1 is for non-pathogenic organisms, BSL-2 is for moderate-risk pathogens, and BSL-4 is reserved for highly lethal viruses with no treatment options.

choices.text: Previous infection in an asymptomatic patient

questions.text: Presence of antibodies against SARS Cov-2 in blood indicates
questions.solution:
SARS Cov 2 was recent pandemic caused by new variant of Coronavirus in 2019,

Presence of antibodies against it in blood indicates previous infection and patient may be asymptomatic right now.

Risk of reinfection is wrong option, because antibodies are seen, so pt is protected by the virus.

Window period is the wrong option, because in the window period, antigen has entered the body and the body is yet to produce antibodies.

Acute viral load is the wrong option, because there is no correlation between acute viral load and antibodies. Antibodies may be present from previous infection also.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Acute viral load – Incorrect
The presence of antibodies does not indicate the current viral load. Instead, an RT-PCR or antigen test is required to detect active infection. Antibodies are formed after an infection, not during its early stages.

Choice B: Risk of reinfection – Incorrect
While reinfection with SARS-CoV-2 is possible, the presence of antibodies suggests some level of immunity. It does not directly indicate a risk of reinfection. Cellular immunity (T-cells) and memory B-cells also play a role in long-term protection.

Choice C: Window period – Incorrect
The window period refers to the time between viral exposure and detectable antibody formation. During this period, the virus may be present, but antibodies have not yet been produced. If antibodies are detected, the window period has already passed.

Key Takeaway:

Antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 indicate a past infection, which may have been asymptomatic. They do not confirm active infection, reinfection risk, or window period.

questions.text: All of the following are measures used against COVID19 EXCEPT
questions.solution:
COVID 19 was highly infectious, it was spreading from one person to other by inhalation, tough, coughing, through inanimate objects.

So 70 % ethanol was used as hand sterilizer.

Face masks were used to prevent aerosol transmission.

Hand washing with soap was also helpful because contaminated hands can transmit the infection.

1% glutaraldehyde has no role. It is high level disinfectant. It is used to sterilize bronchoscopes, laparoscopes.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: 70% Ethanol - Incorrect
70% ethanol is a widely used disinfectant effective against SARS-CoV-2. It was recommended for hand sanitization and surface disinfection to prevent viral spread.

Choice C: Face mask – Incorrect
Face masks (e.g., surgical masks, N95 respirators) were critical in preventing aerosol and droplet transmission of COVID-19, reducing the risk of infection in public spaces.

Choice D: Hand wash – Incorrect
Regular handwashing with soap and water was strongly advised to remove viral particles from hands and prevent fomite transmission.

Key Takeaway:

1% Glutaraldehyde was not a standard public health measure for COVID-19 prevention, unlike hand hygiene, face masks, and ethanol-based sanitizers.

choices.text: It is caused by a spirochete
The organism can be seen directly under the light microscope
Can be cultured on EMJH medium

questions.text: False about Weil's disease
questions.solution:
Weil’s disease is another name of leptospirosis.

Leptospira are actively motile spirochetes with characteristics hooked ends.

Most important pathogen is L interrogans which cause weil’s disease. L biflexo in non pathogenic saprophyte and leptospira canicola cause canicala fever which present as influenza like illness or aseptic meningitis.

Transmission occurs by 3 R

Rat

Rice flield

Rain

It is zoonotic disease

Growth can be done on EMJH medium.

These organisms can not be seen under light microscopy, we have to use dark field microscopy.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: It is caused by a spirochete – Incorrect
Weil’s disease is a severe form of leptospirosis, caused by Leptospira interrogans, which belongs to the spirochete group.

Choice C: Can be cultured on EMJH medium – Incorrect
Leptospira can be cultured on Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium, which is a specialized liquid or semi-solid medium used for the growth of Leptospira species.

Choice D: It is a zoonotic disease – Incorrect
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease, commonly transmitted through rodents, contaminated water (rice fields, floods), and animal urine.

Key Takeaway:

Leptospira are spirochetes that require dark-field microscopy for visualization and cannot be seen using a standard light microscope.

questions.text: False about Ebola virus-
questions.solution:
Ebola is classified under filovirus.

Ebola virus causes severe bleeding, organ failure and can lead to death.

Human spread the virus to other human through contact with body fluids such as blood. There is no vector like mosquito.

Initial symptoms are fever, headache, muscle pain chills. Later person may experience internal bleeding, resulting in vomiting or coughing blood.

Bat is reservoir.

It has nosocomial transmission. It can transmit from one person to other if infection control practices are not maintained.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: It is a filovirus – Incorrect
Ebola virus belongs to the Filoviridae family, which includes other hemorrhagic fever viruses like Marburg virus.

Choice C: Bat is reservoir – Incorrect
Bats, particularly fruit bats (Pteropodidae family), are considered the natural reservoir of the Ebola virus. Humans and other animals can contract the virus from contact with infected bat secretions or consumption of bat meat.

Choice D: Nosocomial transmission - Incorrect
Ebola can spread in healthcare settings (nosocomial transmission) due to exposure to infected patients' bodily fluids if proper infection control measures (such as PPE and disinfection) are not followed.

Key Takeaway:

Ebola virus is a filovirus with bats as its reservoir. It spreads through direct contact with bodily fluids, not via mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which one of following infections needs special precautions to prevent the spread of disease by airborne route (droplet nuclei)-
questions.solution:
Measles is a paramyxovirus - enveloped ss RNA virus

Only source of infection is a case of measles, Carrier are not know to occur.

Infective period - 4 days before and 5 days after appearance of rash

Infective material - secretion of nose, throat and respiratory tract

Age group - 6 months to 3 year

C/F

Prodromal stage - fever, coryza with sneezing and nasal discharge, redness of eye, lacrimation, photophobia

A day or two before the appearance of rash, Koplik spot appear on buccal mucosa opp 1st and 2nd lower molar tooth

Eruptive phase - maculopapular rash which begins behind the ear and spreads rapidly in a few hours over the face and neck extends down the body.

Post measle stage - Wt loss, growth retardation ,diarrhea

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Influenza (H1N1) - Incorrect
Influenza (including H1N1) is primarily spread through droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. While droplet transmission is a concern, it is not classified as airborne in the same way as measles. Airborne precautions are generally not required for influenza.

Choice C: Diphtheria - Incorrect
Diphtheria is transmitted via respiratory droplets but does not require airborne precautions. It can typically be controlled with standard droplet precautions in healthcare settings.

Choice D: Pertussis - Incorrect
Pertussis (whooping cough) is primarily spread through respiratory droplets. Although it is highly contagious, it does not require airborne precautions like measles. Droplet precautions are sufficient for preventing its spread.

Key Takeaway:

Measles requires airborne precautions due to its ability to spread via airborne droplets (droplet nuclei), while the other infections listed require only droplet precautions.

questions.text: Needle prick in a HCW, patient HBV reactive, anti-HBs >90mIU for HBV prophylaxis. What is to be done?
questions.solution:
An occupational exposture is defined as

Percutaneous injury - Needle stick injury or other sharp injury

Splash injury - contact with mucus membrane ( Eye or mouth)

Contact with non intact skin ( abraded skin or afflicted with dermatitis)

Contact with the intact skin when the duration is prolonged ( several minutes or more)

HIV,, HCV, HBV can be transmitted by needle stick injury.

When needle stick injury occurs, a person must report to the head of that unit and then to infection control nurse or officer.

Basic tests to be performed for patient as well as health care worker,

If his Anti HBS title is more than 90 MlU then nothing is to be given as per standard guidelines.

If the titre is less than anti serum and vaccines both need to be started.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Hep B vaccine and IG - Incorrect
Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and the vaccine are not needed for a healthcare worker with a protective anti-HBs titre (>90 mIU/mL). The immune status is already sufficient, so administering the vaccine and immunoglobulin would be unnecessary.

Choice C: Only immunoglobulin - Incorrect
Since the HCW has a protective anti-HBs titre, administering only immunoglobulin is not required. The immune system is already protected against HBV.

Choice D: Only vaccine - Incorrect
Administering only the vaccine is not necessary when the HCW already has a protective titre (>90 mIU/mL). The person is already immune to HBV, and additional vaccination would be redundant.

Key Takeaway:

If a healthcare worker has a protective anti-HBs titre greater than 90 mIU/mL, no further prophylaxis (such as vaccine or immunoglobulin) is required after exposure to an HBV-positive patient.

questions.text: Child with bloody diarrhoea followed by joint pains 2 weeks later. Likely cause-
questions.solution:
This is a case of dysentery. Which is caused by shigella spp.

Shigella spp are classified on basis of mannitol fermentation.

Mannitol fermenting - Shflexneri, sh boydii, sh sonnei

Mannitol non fermenting - sh dysenteriae

Complications are most often seen In infection with Sh Dysenteriae type I and include arthritis, toxic neuritis, conjunctivitis, parotitis and in children intussusception.

HUS ( hemolytic uremic syndrome) may occur in severe cases.

Sever dysentery most likely involves infection due to S dysenteriae type I, occurs less commonly with S flexneri and is least likely with S sonnei or S boydii.

XLD medium is used as selective media for growth of Shigella.

Shigella toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating 60 S ribosomes.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: E. coli - Incorrect
While E. coli (especially Enterohemorrhagic E. coli, such as O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea and complications like hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), joint pain is not a typical complication seen in this infection. Additionally, HUS typically follows acute kidney injury rather than joint involvement.

Choice C: Giardia - Incorrect
Giardia causes watery diarrhea, not typically bloody diarrhea, and joint pain is not a known complication of Giardiainfection. This parasitic infection is usually associated with gastrointestinal symptoms rather than post-infectious complications like reactive arthritis.

Choice D: Rotavirus - Incorrect
Rotavirus causes watery diarrhea in children, often with vomiting and fever. However, rotavirus infection does not typically cause bloody diarrhea or joint pain as sequelae. It primarily leads to dehydration and gastrointestinal upset.

Key Takeaway:

Shigella infection, particularly Shigella dysenteriae type I, can lead to bloody diarrhea followed by joint pain, which may be indicative of reactive arthritis, a post-infectious complication.

questions.text: Graphic MARRO representation of-
questions.solution:
Given chart is of leptospira.

Incubatin period in 2-20 days. Then acute stage last for one week the n convalescent stage last for 2 weeks. And then complication may occur.

Leptospira may present in different tissue/ fluids like blood, CSF or urine as shown in image.

Antibody detection in leptospira

Leptospiral antibodies first appear in serum by end of first week but titre is not detettable .

Antibody titre reaches detectable level in second week

Leptospiral antibodies usually peaks in the fourth -fifth week.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Cerebral malaria – Incorrect
Cerebral malaria does not have a MARRO representation, and its clinical progression typically involves severe neurological signs and systemic complications rather than the pattern shown in the chart for leptospirosis. Malaria typically presents with fever cycles and splenomegaly, not the stages indicated for leptospirosis.

Choice C: Brucellosis – Incorrect
While Brucellosis can present with systemic signs like fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy, it does not have the specific pattern or stages (acute, convalescent, complications) as represented in the MARRO chart for Leptospirosis.

Choice D: Typhoid – Incorrect
Typhoid fever involves enteric fever progression with distinct stages, but the stages of infection are not represented in the same way as seen with Leptospirosis. It typically includes prolonged fever, abdominal symptoms, and sometimes septicemia, but not the same pattern as shown in the MARRO chart.

Key Takeaway:

The MARRO representation provided is associated with Leptospirosis, which progresses through distinct stages: incubation, acute, convalescent, and potential complications, with antibody titers peaking in the fourth to fifth week.

questions.text: Nodular swellings over the lymphatics. Likely cause-
questions.solution:
Sporothrix Schenckii is dimorphic fungus. It is naturally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss and plants. It usually affects farmers, gardeners and agricultural workers. It affects skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is also know as rose thorn or rose gardener’s disease. In cutaneous form, it forms nodular lesions or bumps in the skin at the point of entry and also along lymph nodes and vessels. Lesion starts as a painless nodule and ranges in colour from pink to purple.

If untreated lesions become larger and look similar to a boil and more lesions will appear until a chronic ulcer develops. It occurs in fingers, hands and arms.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Streptococcus pyogenes – Incorrect
Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin and soft tissue infections, including erysipelas and cellulitis, but these infections typically present with red, inflamed areas and not with the nodular swellings observed in Sporotrichosis. Streptococcal infections do not generally involve the formation of nodular lesions along the lymphatic system.

Choice C: Mycobacterium tuberculosis - Incorrect
While Mycobacterium tuberculosis can lead to lymphadenitis, it is typically associated with cervical lymphadenopathy (commonly known as scrofula) and not with the formation of nodular swellings along lymphatics like seen in Sporotrichosis. Tuberculous lymphadenitis generally presents as a painful, enlarged lymph node and not the nodular skin lesions.

Choice D: Actinomyces israelii – Incorrect
Actinomyces israelii causes actinomycosis, which can result in abscesses and draining sinuses, but it does not present with the characteristic nodular lesions along lymphatics. The infection is typically seen in the cervicofacial or abdominal regions and may involve pus-filled abscesses, which is different from the nodular pattern seen in Sporotrichosis.

Key Takeaway:

Sporothrix schenckii causes nodular swellings along the lymphatics, often seen in individuals exposed to soil, hay, or plants. It presents as painless nodules that develop along the lymphatic channels and can lead to ulceration if untreated.

choices.text: Height from where the work can be done increases.

questions.text: If numerical aperture of the objective lens of the light microscope is increased then-
questions.solution:
Basic principle of microscopy - A modern compound microscope has a series of lenses and uses visible light as its source of illumination. With a compound light microscope, we can examine very small specimens as well as some of their fine details.

Magnification is achieved when light rays from an illuminator and the light source are passed through a condenser which has lenses that direct the light rays through the specimen.

From here light rays pass in to objective lens, the lenses closer to the specimen. The image of the specimen is magnified again by ocular or eyepiece.

Magnification - it is the degree of enlargement of the image.

Numerical aperture size has a direct effect on magnification.

So when we increase the numerical aperture of an objective lens of light microscope, we increase the magnification for the microscope.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: The contrast increases – Incorrect
While contrast can be influenced by factors like illumination, staining, and specimen thickness, it is not directly affected by the numerical aperture. Increasing the NA generally improves resolution, but it does not inherently increase contrast. Contrast adjustments are typically achieved by altering the illumination settings or using contrast-enhancing techniques such as phase contrast or differential interference contrast.

Choice B: The magnification increases – Incorrect
Magnification refers to the size of the image relative to the actual size of the specimen. While the numerical aperture plays a role in improving the resolution, it does not directly increase magnification. The magnification is primarily determined by the objective lens power and the eyepiece power. Increasing the NA does not inherently increase magnification, though it can allow you to see more detailed features at the same magnification.

Choice D: Height from where the work can be done increases – Incorrect
Increasing the numerical aperture does not affect the working distance (height from where the work can be done). The working distance is the space between the objective lens and the specimen, and it typically decreases as the NA increases. A lens with a higher NA focuses on a smaller area and thus requires a smaller working distance.

Key Takeaway:

Increasing the numerical aperture of an objective lens improves the resolution of the microscope, allowing for clearer and more detailed images of the specimen, but it does not affect magnification or contrast directly.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate?
questions.solution:
This is the ELISA test. ELISA stands for Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay.

Principle of ELISA is antigen antibody interaction. Here the specific antibodies associate or bind to its target antigen. Only when the interaction takes place the substrate can bind to the enzyme. There by substrate conversion can be observed. Hense positive result Is obtained.

There are many types of ELISA.
Sandwich ELISA,

Direct ELISA
Indirect ELISA
competitive ELISA

In given Image B is enzyme conjugate.

Key Takeaway:

In an ELISA, the enzyme conjugate is the antibody or antigen that is linked to an enzyme, which, when the substrate binds, catalyzes a reaction that produces a detectable signal. The presence of this signal indicates a positive result in the test.
